channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hard-Line Supporter of Israel Offers to Pay for U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem
item.media:description: The move of the American embassy to Jerusalem will coincide with the 70th anniversary of the creation of the state of Israel.
item.description: The State Department is reviewing whether the offer by Sheldon Adelson to donate up to an estimated $500 million is legal.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Afghanistan Breaks Ground on 1,127-Mile ‘Peace Pipeline’
item.media:description: A wall painted with portraits in Herat, Afghanistan, part of a celebration over the start of work on a gas pipeline which will pass through Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, Pakistan and India.
item.description: With hopes of easing regional tensions, leaders of Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, Pakistan and India gathered to kick off a natural gas pipeline.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: France’s New Michelin Guide: More Fraternité Than Égalité
item.media:description: Laureates during the 2018 Michelin Guide presentation in Boulogne-Billancourt, France, this month. Only two were women.
item.description: The gastronomic bible awarded new stars to 57 restaurants, only two of which have women as chefs. A “Me Too” moment pricks French kitchen culture.
item.dc:creator: ASSIA LABBAS

item.title: U.K. Moves Toward Making Adults Presumed Organ Donors
item.media:description: A National Health Service organ donor card. Though public opinion surveys show that a vast majority of people in developed countries favor organ donation, far fewer sign up as donors.
item.media:credit: Clive Gee/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Dozens of countries have tried to address shortages for transplants with an “opt out” system that assumes consent.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Donald Trump Jr. Retreats From Foreign Policy on India Trip
item.media:description: A newspaper bearing an image of Donald Trump Jr. in New Delhi.
item.description: A speech in New Delhi was to focus on “Indo-Pacific” ties. After criticism about mixing profit and policy, it became a chat about business and family.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Trump Announces Harsh New Sanctions Against North Korea
item.media:description: President Trump speaking on Friday at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Maryland. The sanctions are intended to close a loophole in the effort to cut off North Korea’s imports of oil and exports of coal.
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.description: The action was a clear signal, near the end of an Olympic Games marked by a rapprochement on the Korean Peninsula, that his pressure campaign would not let up.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Can a Canadian Carry Off Bollywood Style? Justin Trudeau Finds Out.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada with his wife, Sophie Gregoire Trudeau, and their children visiting Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad.
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The Canadian prime minister wore traditional garb throughout a visit to India, inspiring debate over whether he was appropriating or respecting local culture.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Italy’s ‘Five Star’ Grows Up Into a Real Party, Scandals and All
item.media:description: Santa Maria di Castellabate, Italy. The local Five Star Movement candidate, Alessia d’Alessandro, has faced criticism of carpetbagging and resume inflation.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Before March 4 elections, the movement presented a dream candidate, trying to put forward a more professional image. Even she admits she was too good to be true.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: From KFC, a 3-Letter Apology for Its U.K. Chicken Crisis
item.media:description: A closed KFC store in South London this week. “The chicken crossed the road,” the fast-food company said after a supply-chain snafu. “Just not to our restaurants.”
item.description: The company rearranged the letters in its name in an advertisement, and if a vowel was missing, the meaning was clear.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WOLGELENTER

item.title: Raised by ISIS, Returned to Chechnya: ‘These Children Saw Terrible Things’
item.media:description: Belant Zulgayeva walking with her grandsons in the village of Dachu-Borzoi, outside Grozny, Russia.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Russia is at the forefront of repatriating women and children from the collapsing Islamic State: “What should we do, leave them there so somebody will recruit them?” asks a Russian Senator.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘The Hapsburg Group’: Mueller Says Manafort Secretly Paid European Leaders
item.media:description: Paul Manafort leaving Federal District Court in Washington last year.
item.description: A federal indictment says that a former Trump campaign chairman wired 2 million euros to former European politicians.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: At U.S. Urging, Pakistan to Be Placed on Terrorism-Financing List
item.media:description: Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, center, founder of the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba, in 2017. An international task force has decided to place Pakistan on a terrorism-financing watch list.
item.description: The decision stunned Pakistani officials and could deliver a major blow to the nation’s economy.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Eighteen Killed in Somalia Attacks
item.description: Two car bomb blasts in Mogadishu shattered a months-long period of calm Somalia’s capital. The Shabab extremist group claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rick Gates, Florida, Justin Trudeau: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: France Toughens Stance in Combating Radicals in Prisons and Schools
item.media:description: Police officers outside a jail in Marseille in January during a nationwide strike by prison guards.
item.description: Hundreds of radicalized inmates will be isolated, and school licensing will be more closely scrutinized.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: In Speedskating, South Korea Sees a Fast Track to Olympic Glory
item.media:description: Lee Seung-Hwan, a member of South Korea’s long-track speedskating team at the 2012 Olympics, teaches children speedskating at Gwacheon Ice Rink.
item.description: South Korea, long dominant in short-track speedskating, molds young skaters into champions starting at an early age.
item.dc:creator: JOHN BRANCH

item.title: Chinese Auto Magnate Buys $9 Billion Stake in Daimler
item.media:description: A Mercedes-Benz assembly line operated by Daimler in Sindelfingen, Germany. The company said that the Chinese businessman who owns the Geely automotive group bought a 9.69 percent stake in Daimler.
item.description: The investment by Li Shufu, the chairman of the Geely automotive group, represents 9.69 percent of the German carmaker.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: A Curling Collapse Amid Olympic Success: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Marc Kennedy of Team Canada during the men’s curling semifinal, which Canada lost to the United States.
item.description: The Canada Letter looks at reasons for Canada’s poor showing in curling at the Olympics. Plus, how a film helped Times journalists break one of last year’s biggest stories.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Top Chinese Official Plans U.S. Trip to Address Trade Friction
item.media:description: The visit by Liu He, center, to Washington next week comes as Trump administration officials have stepped up their criticism of Beijing’s trade policies in recent weeks.
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China is sending Liu He, his top economic policy maker and a recent addition to the Politburo, to Washington on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Degas Painting, Stolen in 2009, Is Found on Bus Near Paris
item.media:description: The Degas painting, “The Chorus Singers,” was taken in 2009 from a museum in Marseille.
item.media:credit: French Customs, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: “The Chorus Singers,” worth nearly $1 million, was taken from a museum in Marseille. Customs officials found the artwork in the bus’s luggage compartment.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Anbang Takeover Sends Blunt Message: China Wants to Fix Its Debt Problem
item.media:description: Anbang Insurance Group began as a modest car insurance company in 2004 and used cheap debt and financial engineering to become a financial force in just a few years.
item.description: The Chinese government’s move to tame an ambitious global deal maker reflects an official willingness to finally curb the country’s addiction to borrowing.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER, ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1893: Ulster Men Prepare for Civil War, Planning Mass Bank Withdrawal to Buy Arms
item.media:description: Irish Unionists prepared to go to war over the 1893 Home Rule Bill.
item.description: Irish Unionists threatened to withdraw their savings in order to buy arms if the Home Rule Bill was passed in Britain’s Parliament.
item.dc:creator: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Russian Master of the ‘Dark Side’ in Film
item.media:description: Andrey Zvyagintsev is one of the few high-profile artists brave enough to openly criticize the Russian government.
item.media:credit: Konstantin Chalabov for The New York Times
item.description: Andrey Zvyagintsev, whose “Loveless” is an Oscar nominee for best foreign film, is the rare director in Russia who tackles social and political issues.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Over 40 Should Face Trial for South Sudan Atrocities, U.N. Team Says
item.media:description: A displaced family in Yambio, South Sudan. Fighting has forced more than four million people to flee their homes — a third of the country’s population — and supplies are scarce.
item.description: Citing harrowing witness testimony, a United Nations commission report detailed the systematic use of rape, eye-gouging and castration.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: U.S. Blocks a Chinese Deal Amid Rising Tensions Over Technology
item.media:description: Robots at an automobile plant in the Chinese city of Hangzhou. China wants to use state support and overseas acquisitions to dominate high-tech fields like big data, advanced robotics and electric cars.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: A maker of chip-testing equipment, Xcerra, said it was walking away from a proposed sale to a Chinese group because of regulatory concerns.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Fearing Corruption Inquiry, Former Mexico Party Chief Moves to Block Arrest
item.media:description: Manlio Fabio Beltrones in Mexico City in 2016.
item.media:credit: Cristopher Rogel Blanquet/El Universal, via Associated Press
item.description: Manlio Fabio Beltrones has been implicated in a far-reaching graft investigation, according to documents and testimony reviewed by The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Ivanka Trump, in South Korea, Calls for Pressure on the North
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter, arrived Friday in Seoul to attend the closing ceremony of the Winter Games.
item.description: The president’s daughter dined with South Korea’s leader and will attend the Olympics’ closing ceremony, where a North Korean delegation will also be present.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Gun Violence Draws Scorn in China as a Human Rights Issue
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. An opinion column in China’s Global Times newspaper said the United States should look to China, which has strict controls of guns.
item.description: The Communist Party-controlled Global Times said it was wrong for the U.S. to criticize another country’s human rights when it couldn’t control guns at home.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School (Parkland, Fla)

item.title: Books News: So, You Say You Want to Do the Splits?
item.media:description: The next Marie Kondo? Eiko, whose book “Even the Stiffest People Can Do the Splits” became a sensation in Japan.
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.description: Thank you for your service, Marie Kondo. Meet Eiko. In her new book, a mega-seller in Japan, this yoga teacher says even the stiffest people can do the splits.
item.dc:creator: HENRY ALFORD
item.category: Even the Stiffest People Can Do the Splits: A Four-Week Stretching Plan to Achieve Amazing Health (Book)

item.title: Iran Finally Let Her See Her Husband. He Was Dead.
item.media:description: Kavous Seyed Emami, an Iranian-Canadian environmentalist, who died in a Tehran prison this month, in what officials say was a suicide.
item.description: The authorities say Kavous Seyed Emami, a prominent environmentalist, committed suicide in prison. His wife and sons doubt that, and are demanding answers.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Barnaby Joyce, Australia’s Deputy Prime Minister, to Resign in Sex Scandal
item.media:description: Barnaby Joyce, a populist from rural Australia and a critical member of Parliament’s governing coalition, has acknowledged an affair with a former staff member, who is now pregnant.
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: Mr. Joyce, who admitted having gotten a former staff member pregnant, was also accused of sexual harassment and of accepting gifts from supporters.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Haiti Suspends Oxfam Great Britain After Sex Scandal
item.media:description: Aviol Fleurant, Haiti’s minister of planning and external cooperation, left, meeting on Thursday with the Oxfam officials Simon Ticehurst and Margalida Massot.
item.description: Two weeks after learning that Oxfam staff members had sex parties with prostitutes after the 2010 earthquake, the Haitian government is investigating.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Beijing Takes Over Anbang, Insurer That Owns Waldorf Astoria
item.media:description: The Waldorf Astoria hotel, a symbol of New York elegance, will be under the control of the Chinese government.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: The troubled Chinese company had spent billions of dollars buying up hotels and other high-profile properties around the world.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: An Embassy, 850 Pounds of Cocaine and Now 6 Arrests
item.media:description: The authorities in Moscow making arrests on Thursday during a cocaine smuggling investigation.
item.description: The 14-month investigation was triggered by the discovery of $60 million of cocaine at the Russian Embassy in Argentina.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES NEWBERY

item.title: Unicef Official Resigns Over His Past Conduct Toward Women
item.media:description: Justin Forsyth in 2016. He resigned on Thursday as a deputy executive director of Unicef.
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Justin Forsyth was accused of inappropriate behavior toward women when he was chief executive of the charity Save the Children.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Elephant Tramples a Refugee Camp, and a Child is Killed
item.media:description: A sign saying “Warning! Route for Wild Elephants” near the Kutupalong-Balukhali refugee camp in Bangladesh.
item.description: Dozens of people were also injured after an elephant tore through the camp in Bangladesh, home to hundreds of thousands of Rohingya.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Blocked by Russia, U.N. Fails to Pass Syria Cease-Fire Resolution
item.media:description: The besieged Damascus suburb of eastern Ghouta has become “hell on earth,” a British envoy said Thursday. A man carried a wounded boy from bombed-out buildings there on Wednesday.
item.description: The resolution was intended to allow food and medicine to reach a besieged Damascus suburb, where conditions were described as “hell on earth.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and NADA HOMSI

item.title: N.R.A., Manafort, Syria: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Syrian Militias Enter Afrin, Dealing a Setback to Turkey
item.media:description: People waving Syria’s flag and portraits of its president, Bashar al-Assad, and the leader of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, Abdullah Ocalan, as a convoy of pro-Syrian government fighters arrives in Syria’s northern enclave of Afrin on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Ahmad Shafie Bilal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Pro-government militias entered the northwest enclave in support of Kurdish fighters to broad welcome from residents, but not from Turkey.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: With Dozens of Schoolgirls Missing in Nigeria, Angry Parents Demand Answers
item.media:description: The school in Dapchi, Nigeria, where dozens of schoolgirls disappeared on Monday after an attack by Boko Haram.
item.description: Parents heckled a governor and attacked his motorcade after learning their daughters were still unaccounted for after a Boko Haram attack on a school in northern Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and EMMANUEL AKINWOTU

item.title: As Donald Trump Jr. Drums Up Business in India, Some Ask What’s Being Sold
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. in front of Trump Towers after the project’s inauguration in Pune, India, on Wednesday.
item.description: The president’s son is in India on behalf of the family business, but word that he planned a speech on foreign policy took the controversy to a new level.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB, KAI SCHULTZ and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: ‘A President I Can Be Proud of’: South Africans Express Their Hopes
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, center, during a morning walk in Cape Town, South Africa, on Tuesday.
item.description: As Cyril Ramaphosa takes office, readers outlined their expectations and concerns for life under their new leader.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Macron Aims to Keep Migrants, and Far Right, at Bay in France
item.media:description: A migrant camp along Canal Saint-Martin in Paris.
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron wants to make it faster and easier to expel migrants who are rejected for asylum. But critics say his new law would go too far.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Mithi Journal: Pair of Killings Tests Hindu-Muslim Unity in a Pakistani Desert Town
item.media:description: Family members of the Kumar brothers, including Kekai Bai, their mother, at center.
item.media:credit: Danial Shah for The New York Times
item.description: In the remote town of Mithi, tolerance has been a byword for generations. But a recent influx of Muslim extremist parties is setting everything on edge.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: Kremlin Opponent Aleksei Navalny Is Briefly Detained for Organizing Protests
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, center, at a rally in Moscow in January.
item.description: The complaint against the Russian opposition leader carries a 30-day sentence, which would conveniently sideline him for the presidential election on March 18.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Heads Up: In Post-Carnival Trinidad, the Party Never Really Ends
item.media:description: Raquel Vasquez La Roche, an artist and teacher, works on the framework for a costume for a moko jumbie band at Granderson Lab in Belmont, a Port of Spain suburb.
item.media:credit: Mark Lyndersay for The New York Times
item.description: Port of Spain is known for its exuberant annual Mardi Gras, but even when the Trinidadian capital is not filled with costumed revelers, it remains home to a vibrant arts scene.
item.dc:creator: ERIN MACLEOD

item.title: Greece Approves Bribery Investigation Involving Political Elite
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece told Parliament that his government would not cover up “one of the biggest scandals in the country’s modern history.”
item.description: A report sent to Parliament said there was evidence to suggest that Novartis made payments to politicians.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
